Project File Format Overview
Project Task Teams File Format Exchanges
All base models (models containing the geometry) will be shared with TRSDC and project teams on a regular basis via the allocated space on the employer’s selected PMIS for the Red Sea Project.
The agreed model and drawing formats required for the data drops according with the information exchange schedules from Chapter 7 are:
<For Revit Based projects, all disciplines MUST use the same version of Autodesk Revit>
All file format exchanges must be agreed between parties at the beginning of the project and any further BIM workshops when new supply chain members are appointed. It must be adhered to throughout the life of the project. Deviations must only be made when exporting for Navisworks clash detection. File format will then be NWC, or for different platform collaboration, the use of IFC files is compulsory.
Technological advances and software are being reviewed to allow federated models to be hosted and viewed for a more ‘up-to-date’ collaboration workflow.
IFC Guidance
To ensure effective collaboration between the multiple parties a series of trail/test IFC (International Foundation Class) exports will be scheduled. The export shall contain IFC objects for all discipline specific objects to be produced by each respective BIM author.
IFC File Export Settings
Following a successful IFC exchange trial each BIM author must specify their IFC export settings. These settings should be shared under Appendix P – BIM Guides.
Data Reviews
Data entry will be an ongoing process throughout the project, it will be carefully controlled with regular in-house data checks carried out by each discipline. Checks to include;
Project data parameters have been correctly input. As a minimum the following information shall be contained within the model:
Family correctly assigned.
Type
Level
Ref. to the type specific data in the Specification if that data is not otherwise embedded
Any other information specified in the Model Production Delivery Table
Organization contact details are correct and up to date
No data amendments once extracted from the 3D models
Data has been entered in the correct fields and format (e.g. alphanumeric)
Data has been entered at the correct type/instance level
Model and project protocols have been followed (naming conventions, levels etc.)
Duplicate objects removed from the models
The responsibility for correct data lies with the model in the same way as the responsibility for providing the correct geometry. However, the Project Information Manger (Appointing Party) will conduct periodic data audits and issue reports documenting the results.
PROJECT WORKSHARING & COLLABORATION
Collaboration is vital to the success of a BIM Project. There are two aspects to collaboration; communication between people (under Meetings in Section 8.6), and the control and sharing of the project information and data described in the following sections.
Model Collaboration
As part of BIM, the design shall be authored using BIM software collaboratively and in real time. Where work is performed in multiple offices or where subcontractors and suppliers are major participants in the BIM, the Consultants will facilitate the maximize “live” collaboration practicably possible and minimize the frequency and time lag of BIM updates to the Consultant’s master BIM from external participants. The BIM shall not be created at the end of the project only to meet project deliverables.
The Model Collaboration process will utilize the Autodesk BIM 360 platform – Design Collaboration module. It should follow the Appendix M – BIM Timeline.
BIM360 Package Exchange
The Work in Progress models should be shared by using BIM360 platform – Design Collaboration module. For a better understanding of the package exchanged, a naming convention should be used based in the following table:
Program & Project Code
This is a six-character indicating the Program Code and the Project Code.
Originator Code
An alphabetic code that represents the company responsible for that aspect of the work. The codes must represent the company name, and not the discipline – see sub-topic 6.5 File Naming Conventions.
Discipline / Role
This a two-character indicating the discipline. Refer to the Red Sea Naming Convention displayed in the PMIS Manual.
Package Exchange Code
The Package Exchange Code utilize the ISO 19650 Suitability Code (extracted from BS1192:2007+A2:2016), to define the status of the shared documents and Models between stakeholders.
Volume Code
Two alphanumeric characters that relate to spatial sub-division of the project starting with Volume or System; ZZ is applied when all volumes are referred to – see sub-topic 6.5 File Naming Conventions.
Sequence Number
Four digits sequential number – leading zeros should be used.
Common Data Environment & PMIS
The Common Data Environment is the working environment where all current, controlled project design information is stored and made available by controlled access. It is normally an application or group of applications that form the “single source of truth” for the building information.
A Common Data Environment (CDE) approach allows information to be shared effectively between all members of the project team; giving early access to information and avoiding risk of duplication. For this project Aconex and BIM 360 shall be the designated CDE’s.
BIM 360 will be utilized for all design related information which includes model uploads, PDFs and native design files. The following 3D views are required to be published on BIM 360:
One that contains only the discipline elements
Second that contains the federated model
Third that is tailored for export purposes that free of elements duplication between various design disciplines.
Aconex for other documentation such as word documents can be used as a check but formats unrelated to modelled information.
There are four main environments:
WIP (Work in Progress) – CDE
The working area within an organization’s own systems.
SHARED – CDE
The models that are regularly shared for use of entire project team. The Executive Architect will federate all models and the Task Information Manager contact from each organization will ensure all the latest relevant models are downloaded and federated into their WIP files.
All team members should be using other parties’ information for their own internal coordination checks. To progress to the next stage the information must be authorized by the appropriate person.
PUBLISHED – TRSDC PMIS
This information will have been accepted by the nominated party, in which case it will be suitable for tender or construction (2D model output only)
ARCHIVE – TRSDC PMIS
History of project information stored within the CDE.
Please refer to the BIM 360 User Guides and PMIS Manual for more information on folder structures and interaction with the systems.
Model Upload Process
3D models must be shared at regular intervals to ensure the rest of the project team are coordinating with the latest information. This should happen following TRSDC BIM360 set-up environment.
BIM Models Exchange
Depending on which BIM Model format, the process of exchanging the information across all teams is different.
Revit Models Exchange
All native models should be exchanged using the Collaboration Pro module in BIM360 on a weekly basis. A proper naming convention should be followed – please refer to sub-topic 8.1.1 BIM360 Package Exchange. All consultants should be adding a description informing the major changes.
As the Interior Design consultants doesn´t have access to the Collaboration Pro module, Revit models must be exchanged manually. By having the models workshared in the work in progress folder – 01_WIP – all models should be copied into the folder by using the BIM360 feature: 02_SHARED>Asset folder>Discipline folder. Along with the Exchange, a communication should be sent out to all consultants informing the major changes.
All consultants should access to the 02_SHARED>Asset folder>Discipline folder and do a copy of the models into the Consumed folder: 01_WIP>Discipline folder>Consumed>HW3_06_ID-Interior Design – this folder should be created manually.
NWC and NWD Models Exchange
All Revit models should be exported following the requirements needed – please refer to APPENDIX P – BIM Guides – and uploaded manually into a folder in BIM360 located at: 03_SUBMISSIONS>01_OnGoing Design Coordination>12_IM-Information Management>Asset folder>weekly folder>NWC>Discipline folder.
DWFx Models Exchange
All DWF models should be exported following the requirements needed – please refer to APPENDIX P – BIM Guides – and uploaded manually into a folder located at: 03_SUBMISSIONS>01_OnGoing Design Coordination>12_IM-Information Management>Asset folder>weekly folder>NWFx>Discipline folder.
It´s required that the DWFx models contains 70% of the Omniclass codes included – please refer to APPENDIX J – Master Information Delivery Plan.
IFC Models Exchange
All IFC models should be exported following the requirements needed – please refer to APPENDIX P – BIM Guides. These models are only required to be exchanged on a gate submission and should be followed the workflow in place for the submissions.
BIM Models should be shared according to the table below:

BIM Meetings
A BIM Kick-off meeting will be held with all known supply chain members in order to run through the BIM deliverables for the project. This will directly reference the EIR and the processes for delivering BIM for the project. This meeting will be chaired by the Project Information Manger (Appointing Party) and Task Information Manger – Lead (Lead Appointed Party) who will attend all related team meetings.
This will then be followed by a meeting with all Task Information Managers from all project teams to go through the first draft of the BEP in a collaborative round table discussion and with agreement from all by its conclusion.
Moving forward; regular BIM meetings summarized below will commence with all Task Information Managers present from all relevant project team organizations. If not feasible for members of the project team to attend, then it is the team member’s responsibility to ensure arrangements are made for their members to still be in attendance through communication means.
The BIM related meeting plan will be developed by the Task Information Manger – Lead (Lead Appointed Party) and the Interface Manager. The Design Coordination meeting frequency will vary through the contract period but in general will follow a weekly review or upon request for each of the Design Managers.
Summary of Meetings:
Clash Detection and Coordination Meetings Schedule
The Clash Detection and Coordination Meetings will take place on a biweekly basis or as per client request. In order for this to happen there are several tasks that are required to be completed by each design consultant. The actual days will be confirmed, but the following cycle is intended to be followed.
Outlined below is the fortnightly plan of actions. This will be updated once the design coordination meeting schedule has been agreed.

MODEL REVIEWS
Quality Control Procedures
Model audits are to be carried out regularly on the shared models for their compliance with this [BEP]. The process involves a combination of checks listed below to ensure there are no unresolved issues during construction or any significant loss of data upon transfer of as-built models and record documents at facility handover.
Clash Detection Process Overview
Automated clash detection is to be viewed as the last line of defense – it is always preferable to avoid unmanaged clashes through considered modelling than to rely on clash detection to identify and then resolve them.
Each BIM participant is responsible to maintain the integrity of the models and information and check/review these with their team manager as part of standard model collaboration before issuing to the SHARED part of the CDE.
If a clash is detected, according to the LOD per stage, that cannot be resolved by the construction, consultant and subcontracting team then the lead designer shall be involved in the discussion to reach an agreed solution. Individual subcontractors and consultants are responsible for making changes to their own model(s) only, and where/if required.
Automated clash detection of single discipline models is to be carried out by Task Team Information Managers at all project stages on a >specify frequency< basis using Navisworks Manage or similar software, by implementing the clash rules defined in >insert doc reference<. This is to ensure that coordination is proceeding as expected, and to give early warning of any common issues.
The individual shared models shall be combined for design review and clash detection by the Executive Architect and a federated model shall be made available in read only format to the whole team for model-based reviews and coordination throughout the project lifecycle and issued on to a shared area of the CDE.
Automated clash detection on the federated model will be carried out ahead of each BIM Workshop by the Executive Architect on behalf of the Client as the models are updated. The clash rules defined in >insert doc reference< allows us to efficiently break down clash results and clashes across models and different work packages. This is then broken up by buildings and floors within the site, allowing us to further focus on specific areas aligning with the critical path of the project program for construction to ensure delivery of the project is kept on track.
Automated Clash reports (Grouping of clashes) and any coordination reports will be created and issued to supplement the read only combined model and SHARED on the CDE.
Specialist clash detection should be discussed, costed with an agreed output prior to the project starting. Health and safety/CDM management
BIM and the CDE should support the management of health and safety and CDM requirements. The CDM meetings are to be integral with the BIM Modelling review process and are to be model based. This is to ensure that compliance with CDM is incorporated as part of the spatial design and modelling process. The review process is to include all relevant project teams to ensure the CDM requirements are met. The interactive coordination workshops allow Health and Safety issues to be visualized and a coordinated mitigation established. Integration of BIM can be incorporated into on-site toolbox talks and site inductions.
9.3 Responsibilities and Requirements
Each consultant will ensure that, they are using correct 3d view and Navisworks options editor setting for exporting any NWC files, KAA already provide the NWC export settings.
All consultant need to share their NWC files
Khatib and Alami will create NWC files for BOH
All consultants are responsible for submit a federated NWD file on a weekly basis.
Any NWC file naming changes should be inform Khatib and Alami and approved with TRSDC immediately with a proper mapping strategy,
All consultants are responsible for correct NWC building coordinates. If a building have multiple site position, we should all follow the architectural file export location,
All consultants can check the NWC file tracker for rectify their pending issues that uploaded on BIM360
Khatib and Alami will run clash detection and upload federated Navisworks models in BIM360,
All consultants are responsible to solve their own clashes,
Currently building are combine with respect of Volume/ System information of each assets and clash detection information will be built within this Naviswork model. Additionally each assets overall federated model are generated for design review.
9.4 Weekly Model Sharing & Clash Detection Road Map
All Navisworks models are shared on a weekly basis in BIM360 by the consultants. Those models will be used to run clash detection analysis.
All disciplines model mapping,
Clash detection life cycle,
9.5 Clash Detection Criteria
Discipline clashes are prioritized based on categories sets. Clash tolerance value are change when design reaches to next stage.
Type of Clashes
Hard Clash\Duplicated elements
Soft Clash\Clearance Clash
Hard clash\Duplicated elements
When two objects occupying the same space, it will be considered as a hard clash. For example, a duct placed where a beam designed or, a number of pipe running through a structural wall. Duplicated elements can show in the report and that’s when two elements had been placed in the same places which causes double count and generates a clash. For example, structural column copied on top of each other.
Soft clash\clearance refers to objects that demand certain spatial/geometric tolerances or buffers having objects within their buffer zone of access, insulation, maintenance or safety. For example, equipment placed in an unaccusable zone, access zones for maintenance of MEP systems.
9.6 Matrix and Tolerance
Current clash matrix are using discipline clash method,
Recent clash detective schedule are presenting “Discipline A” vs “Discipline B” a detail matrix with clash tolerance. Each face of the design, KA will be update the stage code and Tolerance. Currently KA is using 50mm tolerance.

Below is an example of the type of clash detection rules and tolerances that may be undertaken.
Note: All grey highlighted clashes will be managed by consultants.

APPENDIX B - BIM Capability Assessments
TRSDC has developed a robust in-house BIM strategy that informs and steers the company’s BIM application within the business. It is based on live BIM project experience and sets out the processes and procedures required for successful BIM project delivery for the entire project team.
TRSDC regularly reviews and updates their live data base of BIM capabilities to identify and maximize the added value that BIM can bring to them during and after construction. Project specific capability assessments are summarized in the table below.
APPENDIX C – LOD Descriptions
Model LODs will follow the BIM Forum 2019 ‘Level of Development Specification’ document (Part I and Part II), unless stated otherwise by the Project BIM Team.
The definitions and authorized uses for each LOD as required in the BIM Deliverables and Model Production Delivery Table respectively are provided with the differences emboldened for ease of reference.
Refer to Appendix D – Model Productivity Delivery Table for the LoI to be filled into the models.
The LOD Descriptions table can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX C – LOD DESCRIPTION
APPENDIX D – Model Production Delivery Table
The Model Production Delivery Table [MPDT] to be developed by Project Teams as per the specific LOD/LOI requirements for each Sub-Project.
The MPDT provides the BIM Forum breakdown of the Levels of Development enabling us to provide a more granular discussion on the requirements for the project.
The Model Production Delivery Table can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX D – Model Production Delivery Table
APPENDIX E – BIM Responsibility Matrix
The BIM Responsibility Matrix sets out the responsibility to produce the information and models for each defined stage and to what Level of Definition.
The BIM Responsibility Matrix can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX E - BIM Responsibility Matrix
APPENDIX F – BIM360 Collaboration and Models Sharing Overview
Sharing the Revit models with other project teams using BIM 360 Design. Through Controlled Sharing Consume Models from Packages. to share using this method:
Publish your models from Revit to BIM 360 using Revit Cloud Worksharing.
Use the Design Collaboration module to create a package and share your models with other teams.
Other teams choose to consume the shared models.
The teams who have consumed the shared model use Revit to link to the model from their Consumed folder in the Document Management module.
Tip: When adding a link in Revit as a team that has consumed a shared model, navigate to your team's Consumed folder in Document Management (BIM 360://Project Name/Project Files/Your Team Name/Consumed/TeamName/FileName.rvt).
For BIM 360 Folder Structure Definitions refer to TRS-DS-GDL-0001 PMIS Design Review User Guide and TRS-PM-MNL-0013_BIM 360 - Design Collaboration user Guide.
APPENDIX G – Master Shared Parameters
The Master Shared Parameters table contains all shared parameters required to be added into the BIM model per LOD.
The Master Shared Parameters table can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX G - Master Shared Parameters
APPENDIX H – BIM Models QA/QC
The BIM Models QA/QC contains all the topics that needs to be checked to be consistent and comply with the BIM Standards used in the Project.
The BIM Models QA/QC can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX H - BIM Models QAQC
APPENDIX I – Models Multiple Shared Location
The Models Multiple Shared Location contains all shared coordinates from all buildings.
The Models Multiple Shared Location table can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX I - Models Multiple Shared Location
APPENDIX J – Master Information Delivery Table
The Master Information Delivery Table (MIDP) contains all information to be delivered per project stage, per consultant. Essentially is a collection of the Task Information Delivery Plans (TIDP) which includes details of when project information is to be prepared: Models, Drawings, Reports, Specifications, …
The Master Information Delivery Table (MIDP) can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX J - Master Information Delivery Plan
APPENDIX K – BIM Uses Matrix
The BIM Uses Matrix informs which are the BIM uses and how all consultants will drive the process to achieve it.
The BIM Uses Matrix can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX K - BIM Uses Matrix
APPENDIX L – Specialist Discipline Integration
The Specialist Discipline Integration informs the responsibility chain of all consultants to make sure that the information produced and needed is captured within the final BIM model deliverables, so that every consultant understands what information is provided, when it is provided and by whom.
The Specialist Discipline Integration table can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX L - Specialist Discipline Integration
APPENDIX M – BIM Timeline
The BIM Timeline informs when the BIM models should be shared, when models are expected to be used before a submission and when all consultants have the gates submissions.
BIM Timeline should be monitored by the Executive Architect (ARCADIS) for the information sharing frequency, agreed formats, and the level of completeness per the MPDT.
The BIM Timeline can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX M - BIM Timeline
APPENDIX N – Consultants Interface
The Consultant Interface diagram illustrates the workflow and elements ownership between Architecture, Interior Design and Structural openings/door
APPENDIX O – Drawing Series Numbers
The Drawing Series Numbers informs which Series Numbers should be used in the Drawing Numbering Convention.
The Drawing Series Numbers can be found on BIM 360 in the following folder:
02_SHARED>HE0>12_IM-Information Management>01_Documents>01_BEP>APPENDIX>APPENDIX O – Drawing Series Numbers
APPENDIX P – BIM Guides
All BIM Guides regarding workflows used during the project development.

Workset (STR & MEP) Strategy | Description
OVERALL DISCIPLINES STRATEY | OVERALL DISCIPLINES STRATEY
ST_(Element Name) | Workset including Structural elements (ex: ST_Columns, ST_Beams, ST_Piles, ST_Steel, ST_Slab...etc)
ME_(Element) | Workset Including Mechanical elements name (ex: ME_Pipies, ME_Ducts, ME_Accessories...etc)
ME_(System) | Workset including name of the Mechanical system
EL_(Elements) | Workset including Electrical elements (ex: EL_Panels, EL_Sockets, EL_Trays..ect)
PL_(System) | Workset including Plumbing system (ex: PL_Drainage, PL_Waste..etc)
PL_(Element) | Workset Including Plumbing elements (ex: PL_Fixtures, PL_ Accessories...etc)
$LR_(Model Name) | Workset including Linked Revit Model name (ex: $LR_ R08-HE2D02-KEO-51-XX-MOD-PL-00510)
$LC_(Cad Drawing) | Workset including Linked Cad drawing(s)

Rooms | Rooms | Built-in room parameters will be used to tag the room Name and Number. Room Area and Volume parameter will be used to be shown in the drawings. Any other extra information which will be imported into the model from other consultants will not be used as tags or scheduling. Tags will be placed in the sheet model. | Built-in room parameters will be used to tag the room Name and Number. Room Area and Volume parameter will be used to be shown in the drawings. Any other extra information which will be imported into the model from other consultants will not be used as tags or scheduling. Tags will be placed in the sheet model.

BIM Kick Off Meeting | Meeting to communicate the BEP and the associated requirements. This meeting is also used to agree and complete the project specific information that is required within the Project BEP. The BEP should be used as the agenda for this meeting and worked through systematically until populated. | One-off | All Project Participants | TBC | Project Information Manager;
Task Information Manger – Lead
BIM Weekly Meeting | The purpose of those meetings is to discuss BIM related items on a weekly basis. Topics related to these meetings can include but are not limited to: BEP Updates; Models Updates; Models Queries; BIM Strategy updates; Information Exchange…etc.
A relatively flexible agenda and meeting structure is prescribed to allow all project BIM representatives to present and resolve their queries. | Weekly | All Project BIM Representatives | Microsoft Teams | Task Information Manager – Lead
Clash Detections & Coordination Meeting | The Aim of this meeting to identifying the clashes and highlight to all consultants.
Task Information Manager (EA) will lead the meeting and visually explain the PDF reports, live demonstration will be present with the help of native clash detection software, if required. All identifying clashes will be record in the PDF and html report, all the consultant will review and resolve clashes.
Reports will be create as per the NWC file shared in BIM360.

Responsible | Check | Notes
All Disciplines | Visual | Ensure there are no unintended model components and the design intent has been followed.
All Disciplines | Intersection and Clash Detection (Visual) | Detect problems in the model where two building components are clashing; including soft and hard clashes.
All Disciplines | Standards Check | Ensure that the project BIM Standards have been followed. Standards check include but are not limited to:
●Adherence to BIM standards
●Delivery format – scale, orientation, view types on sheets
●Detailing – information and section cuts, detail references
●Annotations and Tags
●Dimensioning
●Title block and title text including naming and numbering
●Line work
All Disciplines | File Integrity | Metadata completed correctly including file naming convention and status of files.
All Disciplines | Model Integrity | That the model is fit for coordination across the team. Checks include but are not limited to:
●Content (objects and data) integrity and inclusions/exclusions
●LOD
●Areas inclusions/exclusions
●Spaces and zones inclusions/exclusions
●Schedules including schedule summations
●Tags and tag agreement with schedule data
●Sizes and types
●General notes
All Disciplines | Spatial Integrity | Model information spatial data is fit for purpose. Associated bounding of elements (floors, walls, ceilings, columns, windows, doors), space validation representing room/zone spaces.
All Disciplines | Model Audit | Validation check sheet forms to be completed and issued with all models.

SOURCE: XXX-TTD-XX-XX-PL-K-000001_BEP Template.docx

Contents
INTRODUCTION
Purpose of document
This document explains how the information management aspects of Pilot Project TBC will be carried out by the delivery team. In doing so this document will respond to the Appointing Party’s EIR (doc reference) and confirm compliance as required with the ISO 19650 series and remaining PAS 1192 series specifications. All members of the Delivery Team are required to adopt the agreed standards, methods and procedures contained throughout this document.
shall develop this BIM Execution Plan to generate the Construction Delivery Team BIM Execution Plan and maintain this document for the remaining project duration. The shall incorporate existing processes identified within the design phase BEP into their own construction phase BEP to mitigate the risk of information gaps arising.
Amendment of documents
Both the EIR and the BEP may be subject to amendments and further developments during the execution of the project.
Once the EIR is issued as part of the , any amendments to the information requirements defined in the EIR will be captured and agreed within the Construction Delivery Team BIM Execution Plan. The BEP shall be considered a live document, capturing continuous improvements throughout the construction phase of the project.
PROJECT INFORMATION
General
Table . General Project Information
Programme and phase information
As per the Exchange Information Requirements (EIR) this BIM Execution plan expands upon the phase specific programme information. Details of this are as follows;
Organisations, individuals involved, and their assigned functions are outlined in section 4
Date of completion of all project stages shall be in accordance with the project programme (reference), which is maintained separately from this document
Dates of project milestones including Appointing Parties’ information exchanges are outlined relative to project stages within section 7.2.1
APPLICABLE STANDARDS
As communicated by the EIR, requires Project Stakeholders to adopt the following references.
Table : Applicable standards
Further explanation on the references is included in Appendix B.

The table below outlines project information management functions and responsibilities on . To provide further clarity and avoid scope gaps a supporting RACI table is included in Appendix F of the EIR.
The functions and responsibilities outlined in Table 3Error! Reference source not found. below should not be confused with job titles or other professional designations within the project team. Additionally, the responsibilities outlined below are to be considered ‘key’ responsibilities associated with the project function as outlined in the BS EN ISO 19650 series. Any further responsibilities documented within the main body of this document are also to be fulfilled.
Table . Project Functions

the shall further develop the matrix to reflect the delegated responsibilities of the Construction Delivery Team.
MIDP
For the Master Information Delivery Plan refer to the following document.
XXX-TTD-XX-XX-SP-K-0005
This document shall remain live throughout the project. The Lead Appointed Party is responsible for updating the MIDP as required, including on occasions when a new task team joins the Delivery Team. To facilitate this, each Task Team shall maintain their own TIDP and notify the Lead Appointed Party as the nature of the information they plan to delivery changes.
INFORMATION DELIVERY STRATEGY
Approach to meeting the appointing party’s exchange information requirements
Level of information need
As per the EIR level information need must be strictly in accordance with the ISO 19650 series and will adopt the NBS as a benchmark for compliance. Additionally, information provided information milestones aligned to key decision points shall be sufficient to satisfy the Project Information Requirements (PIR).
5.1
Figure Constituent aspects of Level of Information Need
Each Task Team will populate the required information whilst complying with the following;
Attribute names for asset information shall match exactly the parameter names within Appendix H of the EIR
Attribute names for Uniclass 2015 classification shall match exactly the parameter names defined in section 7.5
Attribute names for performance data shall match exactly the parameter names defined in section 6.1.3.1
Attribute names for carbon tracking shall match exactly the parameter names defined in section 6.1.3.4
Attribute names shall be used only once per information container, avoiding parameters on the same name
Where authoring applications allow for grouping of attributes, ‘Data (Type)’ shall be used for type information and ‘Data’ for instance information.
Level of Information Need shall not exceed that required
As built 3D information model
The shall update this section to incorporate method and responsibilities for the creation of an as built 3D information model.
Structured asset information
Structured asset information is to be delivered in accordance with BS 1192-4:2014 (COBie) and contained within a single Information Container when issued at information exchange milestones.
The requirements for asset information are as detailed in Appendix H, section of the EIR. Task Teams will populate non-geometric information for components within their design/construction scope or as otherwise defined by the Detailed (BIM) Responsibility Matrix, Appendix C where they appear as a maintainable asset within Appendix H, section of the EIR.
Where a Task Team are using Autodesk Revit as their primary BIM authoring software, they will use the Autodesk BIM interoperability tool add-on to general COBie parameters for population. This add-on is available to download from the following location.
It is imperative that this tool is run at the beginning of the project. To ensure information consistency The Design Lead Appointed Party shall issue a standardised setup file, made available at the following location.
Where a Task Team are not using Autodesk Revit, they shall manually create and populate parameters within their 3D information model(s) that match exactly the attribute names contained within Appendix H, section of the EIR.
Transfer of design/construction responsibility between Task Teams
Where responsibility for components transfers between task teams, the following processes shall be applied as relevant.
Recipient task team makes Geometric changes: Component ID shall be updated to reflect recipient task team.
Recipient task team makes Non-geometric changes: COBie.CreatedBy attribute shall be updated to recipient task team. Component ID shall not change.
Recipient task team makes Geometric and non-geometric changes: COBie.CreatedBy attribute shall be updated to recipient task team. Component ID shall be updated to reflect recipient task team.
Additional non-geometric information
Performance information
The requirements for performance information are as detailed in Appendix H, section of the EIR. Task Teams will populate non-geometric information for components within their design/construction scope or as otherwise defined by the Detailed (BIM) Responsibility Matrix, Appendix C where they appear as a maintainable asset within Appendix H, section of the EIR.
Task Team shall manually create and populate parameters within their 3D information model(s) that match exactly the attribute names contained within Appendix H, section of the EIR.
Cost management information
Area and quantity calculation
Task teams will derive information from the 3D information models directly with no editing of naming and values in other software. Area scheduling must adhere to the following terms:
GIA – Gross Internal Area
GEA – Gross External Area.
Area information reported from the information models must be current, consistent with the design intent and in alignment with the terms above using definitions from Uniclass 2015 classifications.
Model authoring for use with CM software
To support costing using the 3D information model, Information Originators must adhere to the following:
All building elements must be modelled as an instance of a 3D BIM object unless specifically agreed by the Cost Manager, Appointing Party Information Manager and Lead Appointed Party
BIM objects must be authored using the correct building category, or IFC mapping to allow accurate IFC type mapping during export processes
BIM objects must be modelled in accurate locations, with accurate dimensions in alignment with the design intent
All duplicate BIM objects must be removed when shared on the CDE
Layered or composite BIM objects must contain material information (defining the materials of the BIM objects) consistent with the design intent, or must be indicated as “concept”.
Any additional non-geometrical cost management information to be associated as additional parameters to BIM objects must be agreed and defined in the BEP
Spaces must contain accurate information regarding finishes, room function, name and intended occupancy where known.
Carbon tracking information
The 3D information models shall assist in the tracking of embodied carbon. To support this, each Task Team is required to link their component to a numeric parameter symbolising the component’s embodied carbon. The numeric parameter shall be produced by the embodied carbon specialist.
Approach to facilitating the Appointing Party’s strategic BIM priorities
To maximise the benefits of BIM, the Delivery Team will work openly to achieve the Appointing Party’s strategic BIM priorities as outlined in EIR, section 3.1.
Table 6: Approach to facilitating the Appointing Party BIM priorities
Approach to completing the Appointing Party’s BIM uses
The Delivery Team approach to completing the Appointing Party’s BIM uses as outlined in EIR, section 3.2 is outlined in Table 7 below.
Table 7: Approach to completing the Appointing Party's BIM Uses
INFORMATION STANDARD
Exchange of information between task teams
Frequency of information exchange
To ensure compliance with the EIR and facilitate collaborative working processes each Task Team shall upload the native format and exchange information formats of their 3D information model on a continual fortnightly cycle, following the shared CDE workflow.
Refer to section 7.2.1.1 for details of the native format and exchange information format.
Table : Schedule for information exchange between task teams
Internal QA/QC
As required by the EIR, each Task Team shall undertake a quality assurance check of each of their information models, in accordance with the project’s information production methods and procedures, prior to being shared to the CDE. Responsibility for quality assurance checking lays with the Task Information Manager, however as appropriate the aspects relating to preparation of the model for sharing may be delegated to an Information Originator within the Task Team.
In carrying out the quality assurance, the Task Team shall check the Information Model in accordance with the project’s information standard, and must check that:
All linked information models and links to centralised information sources or databases have been removed
All extraneous drawing sheets (i.e. those deemed to not be a deliverable) have been removed from the Information Model
All linked information models contained within the Information Model but not present in the design have been removed
Information Model format and Information Container identification (ID) conform to this document and the BEP and remain constant for the life span of the project
Federation strategy conforms to project requirements
The Information Model and 2D drawings are up to date and the 2D information has been derived from the Information Model with no modification in 2D modelling software
All BIM objects in the Information Model present in the design have been made visible
All ownership of any shared worksets has been relinquished
All information models are using the shared common coordinate system defined at the outset of the project
All construction items to be represented in 3D as defined in the level of information need requirements of the Detailed BIM Responsibility Matrix
There must be no space gaps. Bounding boxes used to represent spaces and zones must match with architectural requirements and values and must not conflict
Spatial information must be generated and associated with bounding elements (walls, doors, windows, floors, columns, ceilings)
Modelling must follow the method of construction.
Figure 0. Internal QA/QC process
Once the quality assurance check is complete the Task Information Manager shall notify the Task Team Manager of the outcome. If the check is passed the Task Team Manager shall assign the correct status code to the Information container and upload to the CDE using the shared CDE workflow.
If the internal assurance check is not passed the Task Team shall rectify the identified issues and repeat the check. The Task Team Manager shall notify the Lead Appointed Party if the issues can not be resolved before the schedule date of information exchange.
Referencing of 3D information models
Where a Task Team references 3D information model(s) produced by another Task Team they shall immediately update their reference upon access to a more recent version of the 3D information model.
Delivery of information to the Appointing Party
Information Delivery milestones
As per the EIR, timing regarding information exchange requirements shall be referred to as information delivery milestones. Information exchanges must be supplied to the Appointing Party at each information delivery milestone.
Table 9 below outlines the agreed information delivery milestones aligned to project work stages or asset management requirements.
Table : Information delivery milestones
Information to be provided at each information milestone
The following information is required for each information delivery milestone:
Table : Information to be provided as each information milestone
Note: Native format refers to the file format which the Task Team’s BIM authoring software is designed to work with.
Information Model review and authorisation
As per EIR section 7.2.3, the Design Lead (Appointed Party) during the design stages, and the upon appointment, will undertake a review of the information models shared by each Task Team in accordance with the project’s information production methods and procedures.
In doing this, the Design/ will consider:
The Information Identification integrity – Information Container is checked for correct identification (ID) as defined in section 6.2 of the EIR
Compliance with the project Federation Strategy - Information Container is analysed to check that it has been appropriately divided into sets of information containers keeping the individual Information Container size under the 0mb limit specified in section 7.3 of the EIR
Compliance with BIM object authoring requirements – Information Container is analysed to check that BIM objects have been authored in accordance with section 6.2.2 of the EIR
The progression of the design and design information - Information Container is analysed to check for compliance with the level of information need required at a particular project stage. The development, completeness and validity of geometrical and non-geometrical information is reviewed against the Detailed BIM Responsibility Matrix
The development, completeness and validity of asset information which will be reviewed against the Asset Information Requirements
The development, completeness, and validity of the classification information within the Information Container, which will be reviewed against the requirements defined in section 6.3 of the EIR
The development, completeness and validity of and additional information requirements (e.g. performance attributes, carbon tracking information, etc.)
The level of quality and spatial coordination in the Federated Information Model.
Figure Information Review and Approval process
If the review is successful, the Design/ will authorize each Information Model and instruct each Task Team to submit their information for acceptance within the project’s CDE.
If the review is unsuccessful, the Design/ will reject the Information Model and instruct the Task Team to amend the information and re-submit for Design/ authorization. Partial acceptance of the information to be exchanged can lead to coordination issues, therefore the Design/ shall either authorie or reject the entire Information Model.
Errors or non-compliance must be corrected as a priority with agreed timescales. Actions must be distributed to all Project Stakeholders, via the CDE, by the Design Lead (Appointed Party) during the design stages, and by the following this.
Information Model review and acceptance
As per EIR section 7.2.4, The Design Lead (Appointed Party) during the design stages, and the upon appointment, will undertake a review of the information models shared by each Task Team in accordance with the project’s information production methods and procedures.
In doing this, the Design/ will consider:
The Information Identification integrity – Information Container is checked for correct identification (ID) as defined in section 6.2 of the EIR
Compliance with the project Federation Strategy - Information Container is analysed to check that it has been appropriately divided into sets of information containers keeping the individual Information Container size under the 0 limit specified in section 7.3 of the EIR
Compliance with BIM object authoring requirements – Information Container is analysed to check that BIM objects have been authored in accordance with section 6.2.2 of the EIR
The progression of the design and design information - Information Container is analysed to check for compliance with the level of information need required at a particular project stage. The development, completeness and validity of geometrical and non-geometrical information is reviewed against the Detailed BIM Responsibility Matrix
The development, completeness and validity of asset information which will be reviewed against the Asset Information Requirements
The development, completeness, and validity of the classification information within the Information Container, which will be reviewed against the requirements defined in section 6.3 of the EIR
The development, completeness and validity of and additional information requirements (e.g. performance attributes, carbon tracking information, etc.)
The level of quality and spatial coordination in the Federated Information Model.
Figure 03. Information review and acceptance process
If the review is successful, the Design/ will authorie each Information Model and instruct each Task Team to submit their information for acceptance within the project’s CDE.
If the review is unsuccessful, the Design/ will reject the Information Model and instruct the Task Team to amend the information and re-submit for Design/ authoriation.
Partial acceptance of the information to be exchanged can lead to coordination issues, therefore it is recommended that the Design/ either authories or rejects the entire Information Model.
Errors or non-compliance must be corrected as a priority with agreed timescales. Actions must be distributed to all Project Stakeholders, via the CDE, by the Design Lead (Appointed Party) during the design stages, and by the following this.

have established the following Key Performance Indicators (KPIs). Full details of KPI including KPI measurement and KPI recommendations are included within the EIR. Task Team Managers are responsible for ensure the compliance of their 3D information models with these KPIs.

Identification (ID) conventions
Information container identification (ID)
Each information container shall have a unique ID, based upon (reference), and make us of agreed ‘revision’ and ‘status codes’. For convenience this is replicated in part below, however the original reference retains preference.
Table : Information container identification (ID)
Note: If an information container is removed or exported from the common data environment, then the additional fields 'suitability' and 'revision', separated by a delimiter, should be added to its ID as a suffix.

The following codes shall be used within information container IDs to identify the originator. A list of agreed codes for all other fields may be found within of the roject nformation rotocol.
Table : Agreed originator codes
Object identification (ID)
All objects within information models shall be identified in accordance with the BS 8541 series. For convenience the project’s interpretation of object identification (ID) is replicated in part below, however the original reference retains preference and is applicable in full.

Location identification
All levels, zones and spaces shall be uniquely identified.

Spaces

Systems

Classification of information
Classification is required for all information within information models and shall be in accordance with Uniclass 2015
Classification tables shall use as minimum the version appearing in the table below. Tables may be accessed at this location: https://www.thenbs.com/our-tools/uniclass-2015
Table : Applicable Uniclass 2015 classifications
Where Task Teams are authoring 3D information models using Revit, the population of Uniclass2015 within the Information Models shall be achieved using the Autodesk Classification Manager for Revit add-in: http://www.biminteroperabilitytools.com/classificationmanager.php.
The Autodesk Classification Manager for Revit add-in will populate Uniclass2015 information within attributes named as per the list below. Where a Task Team is not using Revit, or information exists outside the Revit file, Information Originators shall replicate the naming of these attributes within their chosen software. This shall ensure consistent information delivery.
Classification.Roles.Number
Classification.Roles.Description
Classification.Facility.Number
Classification.Facility.Description
Classification.Space.Number
Classification.Space.Description
Classification.Uniclass.Ss.Number
Classification.Uniclass.Ss.Description
Classification.Uniclass.Pr.Number
Classification.Uniclass.Pr.Description.
Risk Register
The Delivery Team’s risk register for risks associated to the timely delivery of information in accordance with the Appointing Party’s EIR has been incorporated within the project’s main risk register, eference.
Review of the risk register shall form an agenda item at each BIM coordination meeting.
Task information Delivery Plan
As per EIR section 6.8 each Task Team shall establish a TIDP and maintain this throughout their appointment. Each Task Team Manager is responsible for ensuring their Task Team’s TIDP remains current.
On each occasion the TIDP undergoes revision, the Task Team Manager shall upload the new version to the following CDE location and notify the Lead Appointing Party.
Location of TIDPs: DE Reference
INFORMATION PRODUCTION METHODS AND PROCEDURES
Common Data Environment
Table : Details of the Common Data Environment
The purpose of the CDE is to provide and Project Stakeholders with a secure, central, accessible resource for collecting, managing and disseminating each information container through a managed process. A CDE ‘workflow’ describes the processes to be used and a CDE “solution” can provide the technology to support those processes.
On this project, the current CDE is owned by . The CDE will be the repository for the PIM for the project lifecycle. The Lead Appointing Party CDE Information Manager has established the project’s common data environment (CDE) to serve the overall requirements of the project and to support the collaborative production of information.
Project Stakeholders are responsible for storing and maintaining a copy of all their project information in a secure, stable location within their own organisation and must make information available if requested, over the CDE. must have access to both native and exchange information models stored in the CDE at any point during the project.
As per the requirement contained within the EIR models must be issued within three working days of an RFI requesting this information.
Trialling of the CDE
To trial the exchange of information models, the Lead Appointed Party will facilitate the initial sharing and linking of project models issued via the CDE. The process for this will be as follows.
The Lead Appointed Party will generate a ‘Shared levels and grids’ model as per section 8.3.1
The Lead Appointed Party will issue their model in both native format and exchange information format using the shared CDE workflow
All task teams will access the ‘Shared levels and grid’ model and use this as a reference to create their own information model
All task teams will issue their information models to the CDE using the shared workflow.
Upon completion of the trial(s) the Lead Appointed Party and Appointing Party Information Manager will report outcomes to the Appointing Party CDE Information Manager.
Collaboration process
BIM Meetings
To establish and maintain a collaborative environment the following meetings have been identified. The Lead Appointed Party will notify via email invite any individuals required to attend.
Table : BIM meetings
Coordination and clash detection process
All task teams are to issue models a minimum of five working days prior to Design Team/BIM Coordination meetings.
Coordination and clash detection
All task teams are responsible for clash detecting their own models prior to issue in accordance with the requirements of the Information Delivery Strategy. The table below details individual’s responsibility to delivery of a ‘clash free’ Project Information Model.
Table : Clash detection and resolution responsibilities
Coordination and clash detection rulesets
To ensure compliance with the project’s Key Performance Indicators the following rulesets have been agreed by the Appointing Party and Delivery Team
Table : Clash detection rulesets
Clash Detection Programme/Frequency
The following table details the cyclical coordination process that must be followed by all stakeholders.
Table : Programme of clash detection process
Each Task Team Interface Manager (TIM) must download and review the clash detection report produced by the Lead Designer (stored on the CDE) and resolve all errors or noncompliance (where possible) prior to attending the subsequent Design Team/BIM Coordination meeting.
Generation, review, approval and authoriation of information
Coordinate System
To eliminate compatibility issues arising from discrepancies between coordinate systems the Design Lead Appointed Party will issue a ‘Shared levels and grids’ model to the CDE. This information model may be found at the location below;
All task teams shall reference the ‘Shared levels and grid’ model when establishing their own information model’. Values for project base point, survey point, internal origin and rotation from true north shall not be altered at any time. For record, the common coordinate system defined by the ‘Shared levels and grids’ model is as below.
Table : Coordinate system
Model units of measurement
All information models and associated design information shall be produced and communicated using;
The metric system
A scale of 1:1, giving distance in units of millimetres
Agreed modelling tolerances
Acceptable project modelling tolerances are recorded below and are to be used during spatial coordination. These tolerances do not represent building tolerances for construction or manufacture.
Table : Agreed modelling tolerances
Drawing sheet
All drawing sheets shall be derived from within the 3D information model to ensure compliance with the EIR. No modifications to drawings shall be performed in 2D modelling software to ensure accuracy and coordination are maintained.
In all cases, information held in published 3D models takes preference over 2D models.
Drawing sheet template
To aid consistency of information production the Design Lead Appointed Party has issued a project specific ‘Drawing sheet template’ to the CDE. This template may be found at the location below;
The drawing sheet template has been structured to include;
Information container title
Information container ID
Revision
Project title
Project code
Appointed party’s logo
Lead Appointed Party’s logo
Security and distribution of information
Security of information
All project stakeholders are required to adhere to the processes outlined in BS ISO 19650-5:2020.
This all project deliverables shall be shared through the CDE only. Project stakeholders must independently take appropriate measures to ensure the secure use of information within their organisation and supply chain.
In the event of a breach / incident compromising the security of project information, the discovering stakeholder is required to immediately notify the Build Asset Security Manager.
Health and Safety
ach Task Team must position a ‘risk cube’ wherever a residual risk is present within their scope of design/construction. This should be linked via use of the Risk ID parameter to the project’s health and safety register.
A template risk cube component is located .
egacy information
Reference information, shared resources and object library
Any information, shared resources and object library received from the Appointing Party has been made available at the CDE location below. Task teams should endeavour to supplement this
The following information is only available in hard copy. Access to hard copy information may be requested by contacting
Survey
Where task teams are required to, or otherwise capture existing condition information, either via traditional measurement, laser capture or otherwise, task teams shall follow the guidance set out in BS 5964-3:1996.
To ensure captured survey data is coordinated and useable, task teams shall comply with the format below;
Table : Defined survey formats
FEDERATION STRATEGY
Information breakdown strategy
The table below defines the strategy for how the PIM shall be divided into sets of information containers. This shall be updated as new task teams are appointed.
Table : Information breakdown strategy
Note: Individual information models must not exceed 250mb to ensure that file sizes are practical for upload and download with the specified IT infrastructure. Where a task team’s information model is at risk of exceeding this limit they shall notify the Appointed Party CDE Information Manager, Appointing Party Information Manager and Appointing Party and respond with any mitigating actions deemed necessary.
Federation process
The Design Lead Appointed Party is responsible for accessing information provided by all task teams and federating their 3D information models into a single multidisciplinary information model. Upon their appointment the Construction Lead will acquire this responsibility. As a minimum requirement, the federated model will be updated monthly and issued onto the CDE throughout the project duration unless explicitly agreed with the .
The federation process will be as follows;
The responsible party will create a federate model using the exchange format information models uploaded to the CDE
The federated model will be created using the software outlined in section 10.1 with the resultant file published to the CDE.
SOFTWARE, HARDWARE AND IT INFRASTRUCTURE
Software
The agreed software, version and service pack for each discipline are as defined below. Only software identified below shall be used to author, coordinate and validate information models. Any update is to be explicitly agreed by the Appointing Party and Appointing Party Information Manager.
Table : Agreed software
Hardware and IT Infrastructure
All Project Stakeholders shall deploy hardware and IT infrastructure appropriate to the fulfilment of the Exchange Information Requirements and this BIM Execution Plan.
This shall be achieved as each Project Stakeholder sees fit, with consideration to the project’s methods and procedures, technical requirements, and security requirements.

Establish a programme for the review of the Delivery Team’s risk register
Review and comment on the capability of the (prospective) Lead Appointed Party to deliver against the requirement set-out herein
Facilitate and chair the information management workgroup and strategy meetings
Report progress, drivers and highlight risks to the information management process to and project stakeholders
Monitor compliance and report against information supplied by the Delivery Team against the requirements set-out herein
Appointing Party CDE Information Manager | | Facilitate the management of the federated model and the production of project outputs
Establish a CDE for the management and exchange of information models in consultation with the Appointing Party Information Manager
Manage the operation, standards, and culture of the CDE
Implement, configure, and maintain the CDE to align with the information management principles defined in section 7 of the EIR
Author and maintain the information management protocol relating to the exchange of all project information
Provide training and support to all relevant project stakeholders for use and understanding of CDE functions
Verify, implement and maintain the processes and procedures for validating the Appointing Party exchange information requirements between the project team
Assess and report to the Appointing Party and Appointing Party Information Manager at defined intervals the compliance of the Delivery Team’s information deliverables shared via the CDE
Assess and report to the Appointing Party and Appointing Party Information Manager that the Delivery Team are utilising appropriate software and have the appropriate level of skill
With Task Team Managers, establish and implement the information container structure and maintenance standards for the Project and Asset Information Model within the BEP.
Built Asset Security Manager | TBC | Provide a holistic view of the security issues and threats to be addressed
Offer guidance and direction on the handling of risks
Take ownership, manage, and assist in the development of the built asset security strategy (BASS)
Be accountable for security decisions that are taken
Take ownership, manage, and assist in the development of the built asset security management plan (BASMP)
Take ownership, manage, and assist in the development of security breach/incident management plan (SB/IMP)
Take ownership, manage, and assist in the development of the built asset security information requirements (BASIR)
Assist in the development and reviewing of any tendering and project planning documentation
Be responsible for promoting a security-minded culture
Brief advisors, specialists and supply chain on relevant aspects of the BASS, BASMP and BASIR
Advise on the need for, and undertake, the review and auditing of documentation, policies, processes and procedures relating to the security of the built asset
Where appropriate and necessary, seek appropriate professional security advice to provide additional guidance throughout the lifecycle of the project and/or asset.

Task Teams
Any multi-disciplinary team or team within an organisation assembled to carry out a task on the project. | Task Teams
Any multi-disciplinary team or team within an organisation assembled to carry out a task on the project.
Task Team Manager | Individuals fulfilling this function to be confirmed by each Appointed Party | Individual responsible for a specific task team
The production of design outputs related to a discipline-specific package based or time-based task
Issuing their team’s approved information within the CDE.
Interface Manager | Individuals fulfilling this function to be confirmed by each Appointed Party | Individual responsible for managing spatial co-ordination on behalf of a specific task team
Managing spatial coordination on behalf of a task team
Proposing resolutions to coordination clashes.
Task Information Manager | Individuals fulfilling this function to be confirmed by each Appointed Party | Individual within a task team responsible for production of information for a given task in compliance with defined standards and methods
Directing the production of task information in compliance with agreed standards and methods defined in the BEP to enable reliable information exchange through the CDE
Confirming to the Task Team Manager that information is suitable for issue within a CDE.
Information Originator | Individuals fulfilling this function to be confirmed by each Appointed Party | Developing constituent parts of the information model in connection with specific tasks
The production of project outputs for the maintenance and receipt of information into the information model
Ownership of the authored model.

Term | Definition
Terms relating to assets and projects | Terms relating to assets and projects
Appointed Party | Provider of information concerning works, goods or services
Lead Appointed Party | Appointed party who has foremost responsibility amongst the delivery team for the management of the BIM process during the applicable stage. Please note that our understanding of ‘Lead’ in this manner is not to denote any contractual relationship hierarchy between Appointed Parties.
Appointing party | Receiver of information concerning works, goods, or services from a lead appointed party
Delivery team | Lead Appointed Party and the Appointed Parties
Where appropriate this term is prefixed with ‘Design’ or ‘Construction’ to indicate responsibility.
Task team | Individuals assembled to perform a specific task
|
Key decision point | Point in time during the life cycle when a decision crucial to the direction or viability of the asset is made
Terms relating to information management | Terms relating to information management
Information | Reinterpretable representation of data in a formalised manner suitable for communication, interpretation, or processing
Information requirements | Specification for what, when, how and for whom information is to be produced
Exchange nformation equirements (EIR) | Information requirements in relation to an appointment
Asset nformation equirements (AIR) | Information requirements in relation to the operation of an asset
Information exchange | Act of satisfying an information requirement or part thereof
Information model | Set of structured and unstructured information containers
Asset information model | Information model relating to the operational phase
Project information model | Information model relating to the delivery phase
Federation | Creation of a composite information model from separate information containers
Federated Information Model | A set of information containers combined into a single information model
Information container | Named, persistent set of information retrievable from within a file, system, or application storage hierarchy
Common data environment (CDE) | Agreed source of information for any given project or asset, for collecting, managing, and disseminating each information container through a managed process.
A CDE ‘workflow’ describes the processes to be used and a CDE ‘solution’ can provide the technology to support those processes
Level of nformation eed | Framework which defines the extent and granularity of information
General terms |
Attribute | A specification that defines a property of an object
COBie | A specialised and structured information exchange used to transfer asset information to be used during the operation phase.
Drawing | An information model presenting a static, graphical representation of part or all of a project or asset
Native information model | The primary data format of a set of structured and unstructured information containers
Object | Detailed information that defines a product and geometry that represents that product’s physical characteristics.
Shared levels and grids container | Information container defining the common coordinate system to be used across the project. This defines, but is not limited to, the Project Base Point, Survey Point and project common levels and grids.
Space | Limited three-dimensional extent defined physically or notionally
Zone | A group of spaces, partial spaces, or other zones
|
Reference | Title | Abstract
BIM according to ISO 19650 | BIM according to ISO 19650 | BIM according to ISO 19650
BS EN ISO 19650-1:2018
(Part 1 – Concepts and principles) | Organization and digitization of information about buildings and civil engineering works, including building information modelling (BIM) – Information management using building information modelling. | Sets out the recommended concepts and principles for business processes across the built environment sector in support of the management and production of information during the life cycle of built assets (referred to as “information management”) when using building information modelling (BIM).
BS EN ISO 19650-2:2018
(Part 2 – Delivery phase of the assets) | Organization and digitization of information about buildings and civil engineering works, including building information modelling (BIM) – Information management using building information modelling. | Enables an Appointing Party to establish their requirements for information during the delivery phase of assets and to provide the right commercial and collaborative environment within which (multiple) Appointed Parties can produce information in an effective and efficient manner.
PAS 1192-3:2013 | Specification for information management for the operational phase of assets using Building Information Modelling | Provides guidance to Asset Managers on how to integrate the management of information across the longer term activity of asset management with the shorter term activity of asset construction for a portfolio of assets.
BS 1192-4:2014 | Collaborative production of information
Part 4: fulfilling exchange information requirements using COBie | Outlines the UK usage of COBie, an internationally agreed information exchange schema for exchanging facility information between the Appointing Party and the supply chain.
PAS 1192-5:2015 | Specification for security-minded building information modelling, digital built environments and smart asset management | Specifies requirements for security-minded management of BIM and digital built environments. It outlines the cyber-security vulnerabilities to hostile attack when using BIM and provides an assessment process to determine the levels of cyber-security for BIM collaboration which should be applied during all phases of the site and building lifecycle.
PAS 1192-6:2018 | Specification for collaborative sharing and use of structured Health and safety information using BIM | Specifies requirements for the collaborative sharing of structured H&S information throughout the project and asset life-cycles. This supports the development of structured H&S information for all construction projects progressively from the outset.
BIM according to ISO 19650 enablers | BIM according to ISO 19650 enablers | BIM according to ISO 19650 enablers
BS 8541-1:2012 | Library objects for architecture, engineering and construction
Part 1: Identification and classification – Code of practice | Provides recommendations for defining format and content for library objects to support project briefing, design, tendering, construction and management of built assets.
BS 8541-2:2011 | Library objects for architecture, engineering and construction
Part 2: Recommended 2d symbols of building elements for use in building information modelling | Provides guidance and recommendations and establishes rules for the design of symbols and other graphic conventions used in drawings for the construction industry.
BS 8541-3:2012 | Library objects for architecture, engineering and construction
Part 3: Shape and measurement | Provides guidance and recommendations for shape and measurement of construction library objects used in building construction and facility domains, setting levels of detail and representations of measurement.
BS 8541-4:2012 | Library objects for architecture, engineering and construction
Part 4: Attributes for specification and assessment – Code of practice | Provides guidance and recommendations for the application of construction objects integrated into BIM working, defining the level of information for specific uses including specifying desired outcomes and selection of products. Covers common and specific attributes and can be used for the assessment of expected impacts.
BS 8541-5:2015 | Library objects for architecture, engineering and construction
Part 5: Assemblies – Code of practice | Provides guidance and recommendations for sharing sub-models of combinations of components and spaces, covering naming, classification and nesting.
BS 8541-6:2015 | Library objects for architecture, engineering and construction
Part 6: Product and facility declarations – Code of practice | Provides guidance and recommendations for sharing information from product declarations, labelling and environmental tables.
NBS BIM Toolkit | NBS BIM Toolkit | The free-to-use NBS BIM Toolkit will benefit both public and private sector construction projects. It provides step-by-step help to define, manage and verify responsibility for information development and delivery at each stage of the asset lifecycle.
This toolkit is an indispensable way of delivering projects to meet the requirements of BIM according to the ISO 19650 series.
| |
Project protocols | Project protocols | Project protocols
Information Management Protocol | Information Management Protocol | The purpose of this document is to have a controlled and standardised approach for collaborating all project information and documentation. This ensure that all project related information is shared and distributed in a manner that is accurate, comprehensive, reliable and systematic, resulting in access to the right information at the right time.
| |
