================================================================================
SOURCE: [Make a Copy] BIM Execution Plan (BEP) [EMEA] Template.docx
================================================================================

Template history
Template governance
This BIM Execution Plan (BEP) template will be reviewed and updated from time to time to support continual development and change within Google. Trigger events to initiate review and update shall be, but not limited to those contained within the table below. Google shall assess impact of changes to the BIM Execution Plan, with consideration of the downstream influence on current projects.
GUIDANCE
Google has provided the ‘BIM Execution Plan template’ to support the Lead Appointed Party, and their Delivery Team.
The aim of providing a BIM Execution Plan template is to enable consistency on a project between all Lead Appointed Parties. The sections of this template must not be changed, rather crossed through if not being utilized, this is to enable the Appointing Party and their Appointing Party Information Manager to align to their information requirements.
The Appointing Party is likely to have several appointments with Lead Appointed Parties (for example, for architecture, engineering, project management and construction), and a Lead Appointed Party is likely to have several appointments with Appointed Parties (especially where they are a general contractor), it is therefore expected for several BIM Execution Plans to be in place on a project. The diagram on the following page demonstrates two typical scenarios for this.
Where notes appear like [THIS], the Appointing Party Information Manager should input the relevant information prior to issuing the BIM Execution Plan template to the new Lead Appointed Party.
Where notes appear like [THIS], the author of the BIM Execution Plan should input the relevant information. The entire BIM Execution Plan template should be reviewed in detail before submission.
For the BIM Execution Plan Google has provided additional templates to supplement, as below:
[Make a Copy] High Level Responsibility Matrix [EMEA] Template
[Make a Copy] Information Delivery Plan [EMEA] Template
Table of Contents
0	Document history
0.1	Governance
This BIM Execution Plan document was created at the conception of [Project name] with specific consideration for the unique nature of this project. As the BIM Execution Plan is a formal appointment resource it will be subject to a change management process.
0.2	Referenced material
1	Introduction
This document is the BIM Execution Plan (BEP) produced by [insert Lead Appointed Party name] to convey the Delivery Team’s approach to Information Management using Building Information Modeling (BIM) on [insert project name]. This document is intended as a succinct delivery resource, which the Delivery Team will use alongside other resources to produce, manage and exchange project information throughout their appointment.
As shown in figure 1 this BIM Execution Plan is a formal appointment resource that responds directly to Google's need for information for this project, as communicated through the Exchange Information Requirements, Part A [Insert link once completed] and Project Information Requirements, Part A [Insert link once completed]. Similarly the BIM Execution Plan confirms any agreed amendments and additions to Google’s Information Standard and Information Production Methods and Procedures which the Delivery Team requires for their own purposes.
Figure 1: Relationship between the project’s information requirements, Information Standard, Information Production Methods and Procedures and the Delivery Team’s agreed response to these documents
1.1	Who uses the BIM Execution Plan?
The agreed BIM Execution Plan shall be used by the Lead Appointed Party’s Delivery Team as a resource to produce, manage and exchange information in a manner that Google and the project team have agreed is suitable.
Each task team will use their Delivery Team’s BIM Execution Plan to help understand their information management functions, information responsibilities, and their agreed information delivery strategy. The BIM Execution Plan also signposts to other delivery resources and tools that task teams will find useful as listed below;
Agreed Information Standard
Agreed Information Production Methods and Procedures
Master Information Delivery Plan (MIDP)
Delivery Team’s information risk register
Mobilization plan
Additionally the BIM Execution Plan explains the Lead Appointed Party’s federation strategy to all other project stakeholders.
[A BIM Execution Plan must be provided for each direct appointment to the Appointing Party.]
2	About this project
This section defines general information about the project.
[The details within this section must be completed using the information contained within the [Project Information Requirements (PIR): Part B]]
2.1	Project description and purpose
[Description and purpose of project].
2.2	Project plan of work/program
This project shall be structured according to [Enter plan of work].
The project program may be found here [Add link to program].
3 	Information management functions
[The Lead Appointed Party shall populate table 6 to confirm details of those carrying out information management functions on this project.
At minimum the following functions should be detailed:
Appointing Party Information Manager
Party(s) responsible for CDE establishment and ongoing management (if different from the Appointing Party Information Manager
Information Manager for each task team
Descriptions and responsibilities shall be consistent with the Information Management Assignment Matrix [Insert link once completed] for this project]
Table 6 below confirms the individuals who will undertake information management functions within the Delivery Team.
Note 1: It is important not to confuse functions and responsibilities with job titles or with professional or other designations.
Note 2: This section should be read in conjunction with all appointment documentation.
4 	Information Delivery Plan
4.1	Detailed Responsibility Matrix
[The Lead Appointed Party shall further refine the Delivery Team’s high-level responsibility matrix to establish the detailed responsibility matrix, which identifies:
What information is to be produced
When the information is to be exchanged and with whom; and
Which task team is responsible for its production]
The [Detailed Responsibility Matrix, insert link] outlines the allocated responsibility for each element of the information model and the key deliverables associated to each element.
4.2	Master Information Delivery Plan
[The Lead Appointed Party shall aggregate the task information delivery plans (TIDPs) from each task team to establish the Delivery Team’s master information delivery plan (MIDP). In doing this, the Lead Appointed Party shall consider:
the assigned responsibilities within the detailed responsibility matrix
the information predecessors or dependencies on information between task teams
the time the Lead Appointed Party will need to review and authorize the information model
the time the appointing party will need to review and accept the information model.
Once the Master Information Delivery Plan has been established, the Lead Appointed Party shall:
baseline the deliverables and dates within the Master Information Delivery Plan
inform each task team and notify if any changes are required to the Task Information Delivery Plan
inform the appointing party of any risks or issues which could impact on the project’s information delivery milestones]
The [Master Information Delivery Plan, insert link] lists all information containers to be produced throughout the project, the associated responsibilities and information exchange milestones.
5	Information Delivery Strategy
5.1	Delivery Team’s organizational structure and composition
5.1.1	Delivery Team structure
[Provide a relationship overview diagram of the Delivery Team’s organizational structure and commercial relationships.]
5.1.1	Delivery Team composition
[Provide an understanding of the Delivery Team’s structure, including hierarchy and information workflows.]
5.2	Approach to meeting the appointing party’s exchange information requirements
5.2.1	Approach to facilitating the Appointing Party’s Information management priorities
[The Lead Appointed Party shall use section XX of the Exchange Information Requirements to confirm the table 8 priority column. The Lead Appointed Party shall outline the Delivery Team’s confirmed approach to facilitating each priority, making reference if needed to sections within the Project’s agreed Information Standard or Information Production Methods and Procedures. Details of Task Teams responsible for providing information to facilitate the Priority shall be likewise provided.]
To maximize Google’s benefit from information management using BIM, the Delivery Team will work openly to achieve the Appointing Party’s information management priorities outlined in section XX of the Exchange Information Requirements, Part B [Insert link once completed].
Table 8 below details the Delivery Team’s high level approach to facilitating Google’s information management priorities, and identifies the responsible task team(s)
5.2.3 	Level of information need
For this project the level of information need shall align with the requirement outlined in Exchange Information Requirements, Part B [Insert link once completed].
5.2.3.1	Documentation
[The Lead Appointed Party shall outline the Delivery Team’s approach to fulfilling the level of information need for documentation. If needed reference should be made to sections within the Project’s agreed Information Standard or Information Production Methods and Procedures.]
5.2.3.2	Geometric Information
[The Lead Appointed Party shall outline the Delivery Team’s approach to fulfilling the geometric aspect of the Appointing Party’s level of information need. If needed reference should be made to sections within the Project’s agreed Information Standard or Information Production Methods and Procedures.]
5.2.3.3	Alphanumeric Information
[The Lead Appointed Party shall outline the Delivery Team’s approach to fulfilling the alphanumeric aspect of the Appointing Party’s level of information need. If needed reference should be made to sections within the Project’s agreed Information Standard or Information Production Methods and Procedures.]
5.3	Delivery Team’s objectives/goals for the collaborative production of information
[The Lead Appointed Party shall liaise with their Appointed Party(s) to define project specific objectives and goals for the production of information. For each, the Delivery Team’s approach to achieving their ambition should be outlined, together with the details of any associated task team.
Reference should be made within the approach to any relevant sections within the Project’s agreed Information Standard or Information Production Methods and Procedures. Details of Task Team’s responsible for providing information to facilitate the Priority shall be likewise provided.]
The Delivery Team has collectively identified objectives and goals for the collaborative production of information. Details of these are contained within table 9 below.
5.4	Mobilization plan
[The Lead Appointed Party shall update and confirm their mobilization plan.
This shall consider:
testing and documenting the proposed information production methods and procedures
testing the information exchanges between task teams
testing the information delivery to the appointing party
configuring and testing the project’s CDE
configuring and testing the Delivery Team’s (distributed) CDE and its connectivity to the project CDE (if applicable)
procuring, implementing, configuring and testing additional software, hardware and IT infrastructure
developing additional shared resources to be used by the Delivery Team
developing and delivering education (knowledge required) to Delivery Team members
developing and delivering training (skills required) to the Delivery Team members
recruiting additional members of the Delivery Team to achieve the required capacity; and
supporting individuals and organizations that join the Delivery Team during the appointment.]
During mobilization the Delivery Team’s [Mobilization Plan Insert link] will be initiated and implemented.
5.5	Delivery Team’s information risk register
[The Lead Appointed Party shall update the information risk register, containing risk associated with the timely delivery of information in accordance with the Exchange Information Requirements, and how the Delivery Team intends to manage these risks. It is suggested that the information risk register is integrated within the project’s main risk register.
This shall consider:
assumptions the Delivery Team has made in relation to the appointing party’s exchange information requirements
meeting the appointing party’s project information delivery milestones
the contents of the project’s information protocol
achieving the proposed information delivery strategy
adopting the project’s information standard and information production methods and procedures
inclusion (or non‑inclusion) of proposed amendments to the project’s information standard
the mobilization of the Delivery Team to achieve the required capability and capacity.]
The Delivery Team’s [Information Risk Register Insert link] will be maintained throughout the project.
[Insert details of how the information risk register will be maintained, and regularly reviewed.]
6	Federation Strategy
[The Lead Appointed Party shall outline the Delivery Team’s federation strategy. The federation strategy shall be aligned to the project’s information production methods and procedures, information breakdown structure and support production of the detailed responsibility matrix and master information delivery plan.
At a minimum the federation strategy shall outline:
An explanation for how the information model is intended to be subdivided into function aspects, e.g. system, work package, design elements. Note as a minimum each discipline or task team are required to have their own subdivision.
Process by with the Lead Appointed Party creates a federated information model
Frequency of federation events
Identities of models to be included within the federated model
Steps task teams shall carry out to prepare their models for federation
Process by which the Lead Appointed Party checks the federated model
Reference should be made within the approach to any relevant sections within the Project’s agreed Information Standard or Information Production Methods and Procedures.]
7	Software, hardware and IT infrastructure
7.1	Software
[Confirm the schedule of each software that the Delivery Team will use]
The agreed software, version and service pack that the Lead Appointed Party and Delivery Team will use are defined below. Only software identified below shall be used to author, coordinate and validate information models. Any update or change to those that agree must be approved by the appointing party and information managers.
Note:
Project stakeholders authoring information models shall allow for full version updates on a repeating two-year cycle, e.g Revit 2022 to Revit 2024. This shall be at no additional cost to the appointing party and must be managed to minimize disruption to the project. Version updates may at the appointing party’s discretion occur less frequently, or by agreement of all stakeholders occur more regularly. Please note that the full year version is managed separately from service pack releases, these should be maintained at the most recent release. Task teams joining the project at a later date must remain in step with those already deployed, i.e. a task team joining the project in 2023 shall allow for a first full version update in 2024. Any update is to be explicitly agreed by the Appointing party, through consultation with each information manager.
7.2	Hardware
[Confirm the schedule of each hardware that the Delivery Team will use]
7.3	IT infrastructure
[Confirm the schedule of the IT infrastructure that the Delivery Team will use]
8	Information Standard
The Lead Appointed Party and all Appointed Parties are obliged to produce information that conforms with the project’s [Agreed Information Standard insert link].
This document details specific standards for exchange of information, means of structuring and classifying information, method of assignment of level of information need and the use of information during the operation phase of the asset.
[The Lead Appointed Party must aggregate any agreed additions or amendments to the project’s information standard within the main document. Any agreed additions or amendments will be communicated by the Appointing Party Information Manager.]
9	Information Production Methods and Procedures
The Lead Appointed Party and all Appointed Parties are obliged to produce and manage information in accordance with the project’s [Agreed Information Production Methods and Procedures insert link].
This document details specific standards for the capture of existing asset information, generation, review and approval of new information, the security or distribution of information, delivery of information to the Appointing Party.
[The Lead Appointed Party must aggregate any agreed additions or amendments to the project’s information production methods and procedures within the main document. Any agreed additions or amendments will be communicated by the Appointing Party Information Manager.]

================================================================================
SOURCE: [Make a Copy] Pre-Appointment BIM Execution Plan (BEP) [EMEA] Template.docx
================================================================================

Template history
Template governance
This Pre-Appointment BIM Execution Plan (BEP) template will be reviewed and updated from time to time to support continual development and change within Google. Trigger events to initiate review and update shall be, but not limited to those contained within the table below. Google shall assess impact of changes to the BIM Execution Plan, with consideration of the downstream influence on current projects.
GUIDANCE
Google has provided the ‘Pre-Appointment BIM Execution Plan template’ to support Prospective Lead Appointed Party’s, and their prospective Delivery Team.
The aim of providing a Pre-Appointment BIM Execution Plan template is to enable consistency.
Where notes appear like [THIS], the Appointing Party Information Manager should input the relevant information prior to issuing the Pre-BIM Execution Plan template as part of the invitation to tender information.
Where notes appear like [THIS], the author of the Pre-Appointment BIM Execution Plan should input the relevant information.
For the Pre-appointment BIM Execution Plan Google has provided additional templates to supplement, as below:
[Make a Copy] High Level Responsibility Matrix [EMEA] Template
[Make a Copy] Information Delivery Plan [EMEA] Template
Table of Contents
0		Document history
0.1	Governance
This Pre-appointment BIM Execution Plan document was created at the conception of [Project name] with specific consideration for the unique nature of this project.
0.2	Referenced material
1	Introduction
This document is the Pre-appointment BIM Execution Plan (BEP) produced by [insert prospective Lead Appointed Party name] to convey the Delivery Team’s proposed approach to Information Management using Building Information Modeling (BIM) on [insert project name]. This document is intended to succinctly summarize how the Delivery Team intend to produce, manage and exchange project information throughout their appointment.
As shown in figure 1 this Pre-appointment BIM Execution Plan responds directly to Google's need for information for this project, as communicated through the Exchange Information Requirements, Part A [Insert link once completed] and Project Information Requirements, Part A [Insert link once completed]. Similarly the Pre-appointment BIM Execution Plan outlines the prospective Lead Appointed Party’s proposed additions and amendments to Google’s Information Standard and Information Production Methods and Procedures.
Figure 1: Relationship between the project’s information requirements, Information Standard, Information Production Methods and Procedures and the Delivery Team’s proposed response to these documents
1.1	Who uses the BIM Execution Plan?
The Pre-appointment BIM Execution Plan shall be used by the prospective Lead Appointed Party and Delivery Team to communicate to Google their proposed approach to producing, managing and exchanging information. This enables Google to determine the suitability of the prospective Lead-Appointing Party and their Delivery Team against the project’s information requirements.
If appointed, the Pre-appointment BIM Execution Plan will be updated to confirm the approach.
[A pre-BIM Execution Plan must be provided for each prospective direct appointment to the Appointing Party.]
2	About this project
This section defines general information about the project.
[The details within this section must be completed using the information contained within the [Project Information Requirements (PIR): Part B]]
2.1	Project description and purpose
[Description and purpose of project].
2.2	Project plan of work/program
This project shall be structured according to [Insert link to plan of work].
The project program may be found here [Insert link to program].
3 	Information management functions
[The prospective Lead Appointed Party shall populate table 6 to provide details of the proposed individuals who will be carrying out information management functions on this project. Résumés for proposed individuals should be provided as part of the tender response.
At minimum the following functions should be detailed:
Appointing Party Information Manager
Party(s) responsible for CDE establishment and ongoing management (if different from the Appointing Party Information Manager
Information Manager for each task team
Descriptions and responsibilities shall be consistent with the Information Management Assignment Matrix [Insert link once completed] for this project]
Table 6 below provides details of the individuals who will undertake information management functions within the Delivery Team.
Note 1: It is important not to confuse functions and responsibilities with job titles or with professional or other designations.
Note 2: This section should be read in conjunction with all information issued at tender.

================================================================================
SOURCE: example_bep.txt
================================================================================

BIM Execution Plan - ISO 19650 Compliant
Executive Summary
The BEP is a process management document which defines the process for an Owner and Delivery Team Members to develop a Project BIM Execution Plan. This BEP outlines the strategic approach to information management throughout the project lifecycle, ensuring compliance with ISO 19650 standards and the Employer's Information Requirements (EIR). The document establishes clear protocols for model development, data exchange, and collaborative workflows within the Common Data Environment (CDE).
The primary objectives of this BEP include establishing a robust framework for information delivery, defining roles and responsibilities across the project team, implementing quality assurance procedures, and ensuring seamless coordination between all appointed parties. This plan responds directly to the EIR, noting the proposed strategic objectives of both the Employer and the project activities to be undertaken.
Project Information Overview
This project requires comprehensive BIM implementation across all design and construction phases. The Delivery Team shall produce coordinated federated models at key project milestones, incorporating architectural, structural, MEP, and civil engineering disciplines. Information shall be delivered in accordance with the agreed Information Delivery Plan, with specific emphasis on data quality, consistency, and compliance with UK BIM Framework standards.
The project team will utilize industry-standard BIM authoring tools including Autodesk Revit for architectural and MEP design, Tekla Structures for structural engineering, and Civil 3D for civil infrastructure. All models must be developed to the Level of Information Need specified for each project stage, ensuring appropriate geometric and alphanumeric detail.
BIM Uses and Objectives
The following BIM uses have been identified as essential for project delivery: 3D coordination to identify and resolve spatial conflicts prior to construction, 4D sequencing for construction planning and logistics coordination, 5D cost estimation linked to model elements, design authoring across all disciplines, and As-Built documentation for facilities management handover.
Additional BIM uses include energy analysis to validate sustainability targets, structural analysis integration, lighting analysis, code compliance validation, and asset information modeling for operational phase requirements. Each BIM use shall be executed in accordance with documented procedures and quality control checkpoints.
Roles and Responsibilities
The Information Manager serves as the primary coordinator for all information management activities, ensuring compliance with the BEP and ISO 19650 standards. The Information Manager chairs coordination meetings, reviews model submissions for compliance, manages the CDE workflow, and reports on information delivery progress to the project board.
Lead Appointed Party responsibilities include overall project BIM coordination, federated model creation and maintenance, clash detection and resolution coordination, and ensuring timely information delivery by all appointed parties. The Lead Appointed Party must ensure all deliverables meet the Employer's requirements and comply with agreed standards.
Task Team responsibilities include developing discipline-specific models to agreed standards, participating in coordination meetings, resolving assigned clashes and design issues, submitting information according to the agreed schedule, and maintaining model quality throughout the project lifecycle. Each Task Team must designate a Task Information Manager responsible for information quality within their discipline.
Collaboration Procedures and Workflows
All project information shall be managed through an ISO 19650 compliant Common Data Environment with clearly defined information containers for each discipline and project phase. The CDE workflow comprises four key states: Work in Progress (WIP) for active development, Shared for coordination and review, Published for approved information, and Archive for superseded information.
Model coordination meetings shall occur bi-weekly during design development phases, with increased frequency during critical coordination periods. All appointed parties must submit models to the Shared area at least 48 hours prior to coordination meetings to allow adequate review time. Clash detection reports must be distributed within 24 hours of coordination meetings, with assigned parties responsible for resolution within agreed timeframes.
Information exchange protocols require all model submissions to include native file formats, IFC exports for coordination, and PDF documentation for review purposes. Metadata requirements include project code, originator code, volume/system identifier, level/location, document type, role, and classification according to Uniclass 2015 taxonomy.
Model Requirements and Data Standards
All BIM models must be developed using project-specific templates incorporating agreed naming conventions, classification systems, and level of information need specifications. Geometric modeling shall follow established LOD (Level of Development) criteria appropriate to each project stage, ensuring models contain sufficient detail for their intended purpose without excessive information that could impact performance.
Alphanumeric information attached to model elements must comply with the project's data schema, incorporating mandatory parameters for asset identification, specification references, maintenance requirements, and warranty information. COBie-compliant data must be embedded within models to facilitate seamless handover to facilities management systems.
Model file naming shall follow the structure: PRJ-ORIG-VOL-LVL-TYPE-ROLE-CLASS-NUMBER, where each component is clearly defined in the project naming convention standard. This ensures consistent file identification across all disciplines and project phases.
Quality Assurance and Validation
Quality control procedures include automated model checking against project standards using validation software, manual design reviews at defined hold points, and peer review processes for complex design elements. Each model submission must be accompanied by a quality control checklist confirming compliance with technical standards.
Validation checks include geometry validation to identify modeling errors, classification verification ensuring correct Uniclass coding, data completeness checks confirming all required parameters are populated, and clash detection across federated models. Models failing validation criteria will be rejected and returned to the originating party for correction.
Information Delivery Planning
The Master Information Delivery Plan (MIDP) establishes the overarching schedule for information delivery across all project stages, aligned with RIBA Plan of Work stages and contractual milestones. The MIDP identifies key decision points requiring specific information deliverables and coordinates inputs from all appointed parties.
Task Information Delivery Plans (TIDPs) detail discipline-specific deliverables, including model files, drawings, specifications, schedules, and data sets. Each TIDP specifies the information container, format, level of information need, responsible party, and delivery date for each deliverable. TIDPs must be maintained and updated throughout the project to reflect approved changes to scope or schedule.
Key information delivery milestones include Stage 3 Developed Design submission with spatially coordinated models, Stage 4 Technical Design with construction-ready information, Stage 5 As-Built documentation reflecting constructed conditions, and Stage 6 Handover with complete O&M information and COBie data sets.
Technology and Software Standards
The project team shall utilize the following BIM authoring platforms: Autodesk Revit 2023 or later for architectural and MEP disciplines, Tekla Structures 2023 or later for structural engineering, Autodesk Civil 3D 2023 for civil infrastructure, and Navisworks Manage 2023 for coordination and clash detection.
All models must be capable of exporting IFC 2x3 or IFC4 files for coordination purposes, ensuring interoperability across different software platforms. The project coordinate system shall be established using Ordnance Survey National Grid coordinates, with agreed project origin and orientation documented in the BEP appendices.
Cloud-based collaboration platforms include Autodesk Construction Cloud for CDE functionality, document management, and model coordination. All project stakeholders must have appropriate access permissions configured by the Information Manager based on their role and information needs.
Health and Safety Information Management
BIM models shall incorporate health and safety information relevant to design risk assessments and construction planning. Identified hazards must be clearly documented within model elements using designated parameters, with links to detailed risk assessments and mitigation measures in the project health and safety file.
Construction sequencing models (4D) must consider temporary works requirements, access constraints, and high-risk activities. The Principal Designer shall review BIM models to verify adequate consideration of health and safety risks and ensure compliance with CDM regulations.
As-Built and Handover Requirements
As-Built models must accurately represent constructed conditions, incorporating all approved design changes and site variations. The construction team is responsible for maintaining As-Built model accuracy throughout the construction phase, with updates required within two weeks of significant changes.
COBie data shall be progressively populated throughout design and construction phases, with final validation prior to handover. Required COBie sheets include Facility, Floor, Space, Zone, Type, Component, System, Assembly, Connection, Spare, Resource, Job, and Document. All COBie data must pass validation against the COBie UK 2012 schema.
Handover deliverables include native BIM models, IFC exports, COBie data sets, O&M documentation linked to model elements, asset registers, and comprehensive as-built drawings. The Employer's facilities management team must confirm acceptance of all handover information prior to project closeout.
Post-Handover Asset Information Management
The Employer shall utilize delivered asset information within their Computer-Aided Facilities Management (CAFM) system for ongoing operations and maintenance activities. BIM models and associated data will support space management, preventive maintenance scheduling, energy monitoring, and future refurbishment planning.
The Information Manager shall coordinate handover training sessions for the Employer's facilities team, ensuring they understand how to access, navigate, and utilize delivered BIM information effectively. Documentation must include user guides, data schemas, and contact information for ongoing technical support.
